body.head.byline: By Simon Romero (COMPILED BY RICK GLADSTONE)

abstract.p: Lucent Technologies chairman, Henry B Schacht, praises entire telecommunications industry for its rapid and dedicated response to damage inflicted on Sept 11; photo (S)

block.p: The Bradys. The Waltons. The Partridges. The Bells. Just one big family.

At least that was how Henry B. Schacht, chairman of Lucent Technologies, said he felt after companies spawned from the old Ma Bell system scrambled to repair the telecommunications systems of Lower Manhattan that were damaged in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., moved quickly to supply clients with the switches, transmitters and services needed for the smooth functioning of land-based or wireless communications networks.
The Bradys. The Waltons. The Partridges. The Bells. Just one big family.

At least that was how Henry B. Schacht, chairman of Lucent Technologies, said he felt after companies spawned from the old Ma Bell system scrambled to repair the telecommunications systems of Lower Manhattan that were damaged in the collapse of the World Trade Center. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., moved quickly to supply clients with the switches, transmitters and services needed for the smooth functioning of land-based or wireless communications networks.

Much of Lucent's equipment went to Verizon Communications, the dominant local telephone company in the Northeast, and AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance company. These companies and others were once part of the old AT&T, before the government ordered its breakup into long-distance and local operations. Lucent separated from AT&T in 1996, when it was spun off under the guidance of Mr. Schacht, its first chief executive.
Lucent's response to the attacks, Mr. Schacht said in an interview, ''reminded me of the best of the old Bell system.''
''Responding quickly to unexpected disasters was built into its DNA,'' he added.
